Welcome to Top10Archive! Though some of us
wish to separate ourselves from society some

14.text:
days, these people have made permanent efforts
to do so. Free from news over the next Kardashian

21.text:
folly or worries over lost cellphone chargers,
these ten tribes have opted for a lifestyle

27.text:
that modern society may consider curiously
uncomplicated.

32.text:
10. Old Believers
The Old Believers aren't what you typically

37.text:
picture when we talk about tribes cut off
from society. This band of Russian nonconformists

43.text:
separated from the Russian Orthodox Church
in 1666, protesting changes that were introduced

49.text:
by Patriarch Nikon. Though not as primitive
as other non-communicative tribes, the Old

55.text:
Believers are stuck in their 17th century
ways, refusing to join modern society. Throughout

61.text:
their history, the Old Believers had settled
in China and Brazil, being forced to leave

66.text:
either due to local governments or harsh climates.
Sects of the Old Believers have settled in

73.text:
an isolated pocket of Alaska, on the Kenai
Peninsula, to preserve their antiquated beliefs

9. The Batak
Some 50,000 years ago, a population of people

85.text:
crossed a series of land bridges from mainland
Asia to the Philippines. Today, it's believed

91.text:
that those migrators were the start of the
Batak, a tribe known for its short stature

96.text:
and dark skin. Residence of the forests of
northern Palawan, the Batak actually face

101.text:
eradication from a host of causes. Governmental
regulation and bans on where they can cultivate,

108.text:
logging, and land seizures have all contributed
to the declining number of "pure" Batak. Due

114.text:
to these detrimental pushes against the Batak,
many are even marrying outside of their tribe;

120.text:
but there is still a small number of native
Batak looking to stick to their traditional,

8. Nukak Tribe
Sometimes tribes do come in contact with modern

132.text:
society and the effects are quite devastating.
For the Nukak, stumbling across the town of

138.text:
Calamar brought disease and flu, which they
were unable to stave. From this contact in

145.text:
the late 80's, over 50% of the tribe perished,
leaving a small number left to continue living

151.text:
in isolation. Solidarity is temporary in a
growing world, though, as the Nukak now face

157.text:
threats from Colombia's expanding cocaine
empire. Forced form their homes, the Nukak

162.text:
originally settled in San Jose del Guaviar,
but were then moved by the Colombian government

167.text:
to the rainforest. After another flu epidemic
and the suicide of Mao-be, the tribe's spokesperson,

7. The Arrow People
The Arrow People of the Envira region along

181.text:
the Brazilian-Peruvian border have remained
a mystery for quite some time, and it's probably

186.text:
for the best. The first recorded photographs
of the mysterious tribe, done so overhead

192.text:
by anthropologists via plane, were met with
aggressive stances. Fearing outside interference

198.text:
and likely a bit confused by the mechanical
flying machine, the Arrow People's pugnacity

203.text:
is not unfounded. In 2002, six years prior
to the overhead flight, journalist Scott Wallace

210.text:
and Indian right's activist Sydney Possuelo
braved the Brazilian rainforests to study

215.text:
the tribe's safety, but turned the expedition
around when Possuelo came across a freshly-snapped

221.text: tree sapling, thought to be an Amazonian warning.

224.text:
6. Akuntsu Tribe
Typically, we picture tribes as large groups

229.text:
of individuals living a certain way of life
in a specific region. The Akuntsu once fell

235.text:
into the standard definition of a tribe, but
when Brazilian cattle ranchers instigated

240.text:
a massacre among the Akuntsu, only seven members
were left remaining. Since then, two have

247.text:
passed away, leaving a group of five to carry
on the legacy of this Amazonian tribe. Despite

253.text:
their dwindling numbers, these hunter-gatherers
continue to remain in isolation, likely in

259.text:
fear of another event like the 1980's slaughter,
avoiding much outside influence and refusing

265.text:
to marry beyond their lines. Before long,
the Akuntsu will be a distant memory of the

5. Korowai Tribe
There are many interesting facets to the New

277.text:
Guinea Korowai tribe, such as the treehouses
built over the canopies of tall trees to remain

283.text:
out of harms way or the stories of cannibalism
that's believed to occur among their people.

289.text:
It's unknown how old the Korowai are, but
it is thought that their introduction to the

294.text:
outside world was not until the 1970's, when
clan members met with an expedition led by

301.text:
anthropologist Peter Van Arsdale, geographer
Robert Mitton, and community developer Mark

306.text:
Grundhoefer. Further contact continued into
the late 70's by Christian missionaries and

4. Awà-Guajà People
If you travel to the eastern Amazon rainforests

322.text:
of Brazil, there's a chance you may come across
a tribe of some 300 strong. These people,

328.text:
the Awà-Guajà, weren't always so diminished
in numbers and once flourished, and despite

333.text:
efforts from the Brazilian government, logging
and encroachment had dwindled their numbers

337.text:
greatly. In 1982, a $900 million loan from
the World Bank and European Union was given

344.text:
to Brazil with a condition to demarcate and
protect lands of indigenous peoples, the Awà-Guajà

350.text:
among them. Twenty years later, the land was
finally demarcated, long after the damage

355.text:
had been done and many tribes people were
killed in massacres.

360.text:
3. Surma Tribe
The Surma Tribe has a rather distinct culture

365.text:
that includes body modification and decoration,
such as lip plates and scarification. The

372.text:
Ethiopian people of the Suri tribe stick to
a common tradition where women have a hole

377.text:
cut in their lips for a wooden plug to be
placed. The plug, like a modern gauge, is

382.text:
increased in size until a large clay or wooden
plate can be put in its place. To the people

388.text:
of the Surma tribe, the larger the plate,
the more cattle the woman is worth. It's a

393.text:
tradition that continues throughout this isolated
group of people, along with other customs

398.text:
such as a household run by a woman and an
economy based on agriculture.

404.text:
2. Mascho-Piro Tribe
In May of 2015, Leonardo Perez was shot to

410.text:
death with an arrow, a similar incident occurring
four years earlier to Shaco Flores, a local

416.text:
guide in Peru. What the two had in common
was their killers, the Mascho-Piro, an isolated

423.text:
tribe living in solidarity and seclusion in
the jungles of Peru. The tribe is sometimes

429.text:
seen on the coast of the Madre de Dios river
in search of turtle eggs and accepting machetes

435.text:
and pots from missionaries, though they're
quick to return to the forest. Despite the

439.text:
occasional sighting, such as photographs taken
by professor Jean-Paul van Belle, the tribe

445.text:
continues to live in isolation, acting aggressively
towards anyone that seems to threaten their

452.text:
1. The Sentinelese
If there's ever a question as to whether or

457.text:
not a tribe wants to remain untouched by civilization,
the Sentinelese will be quick to answer. They

463.text:
won't do so with words, though, but rather
hostility. The Sentinelese make no qualms

469.text:
about attacking outsiders that encroach on
their lands, such as in 2004, shortly after

476.text:
a devastating tsunami hit the Indian Ocean.
An Indian Navy Helicopter sought to provide

481.text:
aid to the islanders but was met with a lone
soldier, who fired a warning arrow at the

487.text:
team. The island of North Sentinel is considered
one of the most dangerous to visit due to

492.text:
its native and very protective inhabitants,
the Sentinelese, who aim to remain isolated

498.text:
from a world that they seem to understand
as little as it understands them. What we

504.text:
do know about them, is that they perhaps know
more about weather patterns than the sophisticated

509.text:
world. During the 2004 tsunami, the Sentinelese
were left untouched, as they retreated to

515.text:
higher grounds before the devastating waves
would hit. This suggests that the Sentinelese

521.text:
may retain esoteric knowledge of the weather
and environment that we could possibly learn
